title: Format p-value — format_p_value
text: format_p_value converts p-values raw numeric form string presenting tables.

title: Format p-value — format_p_value
text: p_value (numeric numeric vector) p-value

title: Format p-value — format_p_value
text: (character character vector) formatted p-value

title: Format p-value — format_p_value
code: format_p_value(0.0001) #> [1] "<0.001" format_p_value(0.0086) #> [1] "0.009" format_p_value(0.0097) #> [1] "0.01" format_p_value(0.0456) #> [1] "0.046" format_p_value(0.0495) #> [1] "0.0495"  # Rounding follows IEEE 754 standard so rounding of 5 may not be up format_p_value(0.0085) #> [1] "0.009" format_p_value(0.055) #> [1] "0.06"

what: Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
title: Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
text: get_regression_presentation_template creates data.frame template lays variables model e.g. levels factor variable.

title: Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
text: model (glm object) stats::glm model object

title: Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
text: (data.frame) template left join unto present regression results

title: Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
text: get_regression_presentation_template incorporated tabulate_glm_result, create table GLM results presentation Rmarkdown document.

title: Get presentation template for a generalised linear model — get_regression_presentation_template
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union if (require("mlbench") & require("forcats")) {   data(BostonHousing2, package = "mlbench")    glm(medv ~ crim + zn + indus + town + rm + age + dis,     data = BostonHousing2 %>%       filter(town %in% c(         "Newton", "Boston South Boston", "Boston Roxbury",         "Somerville", "Boston Savin Hill", "Cambridge"       )) %>%       dplyr::mutate_at("town", forcats::fct_drop),     family = gaussian(link = "identity")   ) %>%     get_regression_presentation_template() } #> Loading required package: mlbench #> Loading required package: forcats #>          variable_name   var0                     var #> 1                 crim header                    crim #> 2                   zn header                      zn #> 3                indus header                   indus #> 4                 town header                    <NA> #> 5       Boston Roxbury    Ref                    <NA> #> 6    Boston Savin Hill   <NA>   townBoston Savin Hill #> 7  Boston South Boston   <NA> townBoston South Boston #> 8            Cambridge   <NA>           townCambridge #> 9               Newton   <NA>              townNewton #> 10          Somerville   <NA>          townSomerville #> 11                  rm header                      rm #> 12                 age header                     age #> 13                 dis header                     dis

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

what: Plot a histogram from a MatchIt object — plot_propensity_score_histogram
title: Plot a histogram from a MatchIt object — plot_propensity_score_histogram
text: plot_propensity_score_histogram plots mirrored histogram enables visual inspection distribution propensity scores treatment vs control group.

title: Plot a histogram from a MatchIt object — plot_propensity_score_histogram
code: plot_propensity_score_histogram(   matchit_obj,   trt_control_var,   trt_label,   control_label,   is_after_matching = TRUE,   num_bins = 30 )

title: Plot a histogram from a MatchIt object — plot_propensity_score_histogram
text: matchit_obj (matchit object) MatchIt::matchit object MatchIt R package trt_control_var (quosure) variable stores treatment/control grouping trt_label (character) value treatment group trt_control_var (e.g. video_consult_grp) control_label (character) value control group trt_control_var (e.g. face_to_face_grp) is_after_matching (logical) TRUE -matching plot, FALSE -matching plot num_bins (numeric) number bins histogram

title: Plot a histogram from a MatchIt object — plot_propensity_score_histogram
text: ggplot object

title: Plot a histogram from a MatchIt object — plot_propensity_score_histogram
code: library(MatchIt)  MatchIt::matchit(   treat ~ age + educ + race + married + nodegree + re78,   data = lalonde %>% dplyr::mutate(trt_control = ifelse(treat == 1, "trt", "control")),   method = "nearest",   ratio = 2 ) %>%   plot_propensity_score_histogram(trt_control, "trt", "control",     is_after_matching = TRUE, num_bins = 30   )

title: Rename column names — rename_colnames
text: rename_colnames cleans column names raw data frame make.names, replaces whitespaces separator choice converts lower case.

title: Rename column names — rename_colnames
text: df (data.frame) data form data frame separator (character) Separator replace whitespaces add_labels (logical) TRUE want original column names used labels, FALSE otherwise

title: Rename column names — rename_colnames
text: (data.frame) data cleaned column names

title: Rename column names — rename_colnames
code: if (require("tibble")) {   print("Original data")   data <- tibble::tibble(     "Column A!!!" = sample(1:100, 5, replace = TRUE),     "Column - 2;" = runif(5, min = 0, max = 1),     "Column: (3)" = sample(letters, 5, replace = TRUE),     "<Column 4...>" = sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 5, replace = TRUE)   )   data %>% print()    print("Data after renaming columns")   data %>%     rename_colnames() %>%     print() } #> Loading required package: tibble #> [1] "Original data" #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   `Column A!!!` `Column - 2;` `Column: (3)` `<Column 4...>` #>           <int>         <dbl> <chr>         <lgl>           #> 1            45        0.733  e             FALSE           #> 2            23        0.773  x             TRUE            #> 3            76        0.875  o             TRUE            #> 4            63        0.175  m             FALSE           #> 5            47        0.0342 b             TRUE            #> [1] "Data after renaming columns" #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   column_a column_2 column_3 x_column_4 #>      <int>    <dbl> <chr>    <lgl>      #> 1       45   0.733  e        FALSE      #> 2       23   0.773  x        TRUE       #> 3       76   0.875  o        TRUE       #> 4       63   0.175  m        FALSE      #> 5       47   0.0342 b        TRUE

title: Safe left join — safe_left_join
text: safe_left_join wrapper around dplyr::left_join additional check additional rows joined unto left data frame.

title: Safe left join — safe_left_join
text: left_df (data.frame) Left data frame left join right_df (data.frame) Right data frame join unto left data frame ... (ellipsis) Extra arguments pass dplyr::left_join

title: Safe left join — safe_left_join
text: (data.frame) left_df, left data frame

title: Safe left join — safe_left_join
code: # Left table ---------------------------------------------------------------- left_table <- data.frame(   ID = sprintf(     "%s%s",     sample(1000:2000, 5, replace = TRUE),     sample(letters, 5, replace = TRUE)   ),   column_b = runif(5, min = 0, max = 1),   column_c = sample(letters, 5, replace = TRUE) ) print(left_table) #>      ID  column_b column_c #> 1 1772f 0.7064338        u #> 2 1468d 0.9485766        f #> 3 1299p 0.1803388        i #> 4 1956b 0.2168999        v #> 5 1545c 0.6801629        j  # Right table --------------------------------------------------------------- right_table <- data.frame(   ID = left_table$ID,   column_d = runif(5, min = 10, max = 50) ) print(right_table) #>      ID column_d #> 1 1772f 49.62849 #> 2 1468d 48.82084 #> 3 1299p 25.56731 #> 4 1956b 28.44746 #> 5 1545c 22.60967  # Left table has same row count after join ---------------------------------- left_table %>%   safe_left_join(right_table, by = "ID") %>%   print() #>      ID  column_b column_c column_d #> 1 1772f 0.7064338        u 49.62849 #> 2 1468d 0.9485766        f 48.82084 #> 3 1299p 0.1803388        i 25.56731 #> 4 1956b 0.2168999        v 28.44746 #> 5 1545c 0.6801629        j 22.60967  # Right table with duplicated ID -------------------------------------------- right_table2 <- rbind(right_table, data.frame(   ID = right_table[3:4, "ID"],   column_d = runif(2, min = 10, max = 50) )) print(right_table2) #>      ID column_d #> 1 1772f 49.62849 #> 2 1468d 48.82084 #> 3 1299p 25.56731 #> 4 1956b 28.44746 #> 5 1545c 22.60967 #> 6 1299p 16.98704 #> 7 1956b 31.26294  # Left table has more rows after join --------------------------------------- try(   left_table %>%     safe_left_join(right_table2, by = "ID") %>%     print() ) #> Error : Row count after join not equals row count before join

title: Tabulate GLM result — tabulate_glm_result
text: tabulate_glm_result tabulates GLM results presentation Rmarkdown document.

title: Tabulate GLM result — tabulate_glm_result
text: model (glm object) stats::glm model object conf_lvl (numeric) Confidence level. default value 0.95 95% confidence level. default, summary.glm function R computes p-values using Wald method. consistent, compute confidence intervals using Wald method via stats::confint.default. See discussion post exponentiate (logical) TRUE beta-coefficients exponentiated expressed odds ratios. TRUE, confidence intervals also exponentiated correspondingly num_dp (numeric) Number decimal places present beta coefficients/odds ratios confidence intervals

title: Tabulate GLM result — tabulate_glm_result
text: (data.frame) Table GLM results

title: Write to excel — write_to_excel
text: write_to_excel enables write data excel workbook.

title: Write to excel — write_to_excel
text: output_table (data.frame) Data want write excel workbook (character) File path excel workbook workbook exist, created workbook exists, data written specified sheet sheet_name (character) Name excel sheet write data Defaults system time execution none provided

title: Write to excel — write_to_excel
text: None

title: Write to excel — write_to_excel
code: # Load data data(BostonHousing2, package = "mlbench")  # Write data to excel file in temp directory output_file_path_1 <- file.path(tempdir(), "file1.xlsx") write_to_excel(BostonHousing2, output_file_path_1, sheet_name = "my_sheet") print(list.files(tempdir(), pattern = "\\.(xlsx|xls)$")) #> [1] "file1.xlsx"  # Clean up file in temp directory unlink(output_file_path_1) print(list.files(tempdir(), pattern = "\\.(xlsx|xls)$")) #> character(0)
